paper_metadata.title: Economic assistance program impact on depression in post-conflict Northern Uganda

component_a_cash_support.cash_evidence_citation: Participants in treatment villages received training, start-up capital, and follow-up support.

study_characteristics.outcomes_evidence_citation: Sixteen months after the program, monthly cash earnings doubled from UGX 22 523 to 51 124, non-household and non-farm businesses doubled, and cash savings roughly quadrupled. There was no measurable effect on a locally derived measure of symptoms of depression.
study_characteristics.design_evidence_citation: This study used a cluster-randomized design to test the hypothesis that a poverty alleviation program would improve economic security and reduce symptoms of depression

evidence_citations.program_name_citation: This study used a cluster-randomized design to test the hypothesis that a poverty alleviation program would improve economic security
evidence_citations.country_citation: By 2009, two decades of war and widespread displacement left the majority of the population of Northern Uganda impoverished.
evidence_citations.target_population_citation: Community committees were asked to identify the most vulnerable women (and some men) to participate.
